questions.explanation: Rise time tr is the time for the response to go from 10% to 90% of the final steady-state value. It indicates how fast the system responds to inputs.
ζ < 1 means underdamped. The response will oscillate and overshoot before settling. ζ = 0.5 gives about 16% overshoot. Common in responsive control systems.
ζ = 1 is the boundary between oscillatory and non-oscillatory. It reaches final value quickest without overshooting. Ideal for systems where overshoot is unacceptable.
After 4 time constants (t = 4τ = 4/σ), e^(-σt) = e^(-4) ≈ 0.018 ≈ 2%. The exponential envelope has decayed to within 2% of zero.
Mp = exp(-πζ/√(1-ζ²)) depends only on ζ. Natural frequency ωn affects timing but not overshoot magnitude. Lower ζ = more overshoot.
Higher damped frequency ωd means shorter period and earlier peak. tp inversely proportional to ωd. Fast oscillation = quick first peak.
Using Mp = exp(-πζ/√(1-ζ²)) = 0.05, solving gives ζ ≈ 0.69. ζ = 0.7 is often used as a design target for good balance of speed and overshoot.

questions.prompt: Steady-state error for type-0 system with step input:
questions.explanation: Type-0 system has finite DC gain Kp. For step input, ess = 1/(1+Kp). Higher gain reduces error but can't eliminate it for type-0. Need type-1 for zero step error.

questions.prompt: Adding a zero near dominant poles:
questions.explanation: LHP zeros near dominant poles increase overshoot and speed up response. The zero adds a derivative-like effect. This is often used to improve rise time.
Transients settle after the settling time ts. By definition, after ts the response stays within 2% of final value. Transients haven't fully died by tr or tp.
